source.raw_text:
Boxing is a full-body workout demanding power from legs and hips, rotation from the core (abs, obliques, lower back), and explosive force from the shoulders (deltoids, serratus anterior) and arms (triceps, biceps), coordinated through complex movement patterns like rotational force generation, dynamic stabilization, and horizontal/vertical pushing/pulling for a powerful, balanced punch and agile footwork, relying on the entire kinetic chain for effective striking and defense. [1, 2, 3, 4]  
Key Muscles Worked: 

• Core: Abs (rectus abdominis, transverse abdominis), obliques, lower back for rotational power and stability. 
• Lower Body: Glutes, quadriceps, calves, hamstrings, hip flexors for generating power from the ground up and maintaining stance. 
• Upper Body (Pushing): Deltoids, pectorals, triceps for extending the punch. 
• Upper Body (Pulling/Stabilizing): Biceps (retraction, hooks), latissimus dorsi, rhomboids, trapezius (balancing push power). 
• Shoulder Girdle: Serratus anterior ("boxer's muscle") for scapular protraction (punching motion). [1, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9]  

Key Movement Patterns: 

• Rotational Power: Initiated in the legs, transferred through the hips and core to the upper body, like a coiled spring releasing energy. 
• Horizontal Pushing: Jabs, crosses, hooks (chest, shoulders, triceps). 
• Vertical Pushing: Uppercuts (shoulders, triceps). 
• Pulling/Retraction: Returning the arm to guard (biceps, back muscles). 
• Dynamic Stabilization: Core and lower body maintaining balance and stance during movement. 
• Lower Body Drive: Constant shifting, bouncing, and driving power from the ground (hip/knee dominance). [1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 9, 10]  

In essence, boxing uses the whole body as a kinetic chain, turning ground force into punching power through coordinated muscle engagement and movement patterns. [2, 11]  

**Citations:**
